title: Quintain (poetry)
text:
A quintain or pentastich is any <a href="poetic">poetic</a> form containing five lines. Examples include the <a href="tanka">tanka</a>, the <a href="cinquain">cinquain</a>, the <a href="Quintilla%20%28poetry%29">quintilla</a>, Shakespeare's <a href="Sonnet%2099">Sonnet 99</a>, and the <a href="limerick%20%28poetry%29">limerick</a>.
Example.
 <poem>
 Sonnet 99, the first stanza:
The forward violet thus did I chide:
Sweet thief, whence didst thou steal thy sweet that smells
If not from my love’s breath? The purple pride
Which on thy soft cheek for complexion dwells,
In my love’s veins thou hast too grossly dyed.
 --<a href="William%20Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>
</poem>
<poem>
 Autumn Song
 Know'st thou not at the fall of the leaf 
 How the heart feels a languid grief 
 Laid on it for a covering, 
 And how sleep seems a goodly thing 
 In Autumn at the fall of the leaf?
 And how the swift beat of the brain 
 Falters because it is in vain, 
 In Autumn at the fall of the leaf 
 Knowest thou not? and how the chief 
 Of joys seems—not to suffer pain?
 Know'st thou not at the fall of the leaf 
 How the soul feels like a dried sheaf 
 Bound up at length for harvesting, 
 And how death seems a comely thing 
 In Autumn at the fall of the leaf?
 --<a href="Dante%20Gabriel%20Rossetti">Dante Gabriel Rossetti</a>
</poem>
